facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 106 of 1956 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 106 of 1956. Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated the 7th April, 1956, of the former Judicial Commissioners Court, Vindhya Pradesh, Rewa in Misc. Crl. Application No. 70 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated 7th April 1956 of the Judicial Commissioners Court Vindhya Pradesh Rewa in Misc Crl Application No 70 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 106 of 1956. Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated the 7th April, 1956, of the former Judicial Commissioners Court, Vindhya Pradesh, Rewa in Misc. Crl. Application No. 70 of 1956. D. Mathur for the Appellant.

facts.text: Appellant was convicted under s. 307 Indian Penal Code and s. 19 f of the Indian Arms Act by the Sessions Judge of Chatarpur.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was companyvicted under s. 307, Indian Penal Code and s. 19 f  of the Indian Arms Act by the Sessions Judge of Chatarpur. He was sentenced to 10 years rigorous imprisonment under s. 307, Indian Penal Code and to 3 years rigorous imprisonment under s. 19 f  of the Indian Arms Act.

facts.text: Appellant sentenced to 10 years rigorous imprisonment under s. 307 Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: He was sentenced to 10 years rigorous imprisonment under s. 307, Indian Penal Code and to 3 years rigorous imprisonment under s. 19 f  of the Indian Arms Act. He filed an appeal while he was in jail which was summarily dismissed on merits on October 28, 1955.

facts.text: Appellant sentenced to 3 years rigorous imprisonment under s. 19 f of the Indian Arms Act.

anchor.surface_text: and to 3 years rigorous imprisonment under s. 19 f  of the Indian Arms Act. He filed an appeal while he was in jail which was summarily dismissed on merits on October 28, 1955. Thereafter, on October 31, 1955, he filed a Memorandum of Appeal through a pleader which was rejected on November 1, 1955,

facts.text: Appellant filed an appeal while in jail which was summarily dismissed on merits on October 28 1955.

anchor.surface_text: He filed an appeal while he was in jail which was summarily dismissed on merits on October 28, 1955. Thereafter, on October 31, 1955, he filed a Memorandum of Appeal through a pleader which was rejected on November 1, 1955, on the ground that it was number maintainable owing to his appeal from jail under s. 420 of the Code of Criminal Procedure having been dismissed on October 28, 1955.

facts.text: Appellant filed Memorandum of Appeal through pleader on October 31 1955 which was rejected on November 1 1955 as not maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, on October 31, 1955, he filed a Memorandum of Appeal through a pleader which was rejected on November 1, 1955, on the ground that it was number maintainable owing to his appeal from jail under s. 420 of the Code of Criminal Procedure having been dismissed on October 28, 1955. Thereafter, he filed a petition before the Judicial Commissioner that the order dated October 28, 1955, dismissing his appeal from jail should be reviewed and his appeal should be reheard on merits.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition before Judicial Commissioner for review of order dated October 28 1955 which was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, he filed a petition before the Judicial Commissioner that the order dated October 28, 1955, dismissing his appeal from jail should be reviewed and his appeal should be reheard on merits. This petition was also dismissed by the Judicial Commissioner.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner granted certificate under Art. 132(1) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Commissioner was of the opinion that numberground had been established for grant of a certificate under Art. 134 c  but a certificate should issue under Art. 132 1 . The only question for determination in this appeal is whether the case involves any substantial question of law as to the interpretation of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellant prayed for certificate under Arts. 132 and 134(1)(c) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had prayed for a certificate under Arts. 132 and 134 c  of the Constitution. The Judicial Commissioner was of the opinion that numberground had been established for grant of a certificate under Art. 134 c  but a certificate should issue under Art. 132 1 .

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner opined no ground for certificate under Art. 134(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Commissioner was of the opinion that numberground had been established for grant of a certificate under Art. 134 c  but a certificate should issue under Art. 132 1 .

facts.text: Court of Judicial Commissioner Vindhya Pradesh was a High Court for purposes of the Code.

anchor.surface_text: The Court of Judicial Commissioner, Vindhya Pradesh, was a High Court for the purposes of the Code. The appeal of the appellant from jail against his companyviction and sentence by the Sessions Judge therefore lay to the Court of the Judicial Commissioner.

facts.text: Appeal from jail presented under s.420 through jail authorities to Judicial Commissioner summarily dismissed on October 28 1955.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the appellant was in jail and he presented his petition of appeal to the Court of the Judicial Commissioner under s. 420 through the jail authorities. It was summarily dismissed on merits on October 28, 1955.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered by IMAM J. on November 18 1960.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. November 18. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by IMAM, J.-The Judicial Commissioner of Vindhya Pradesh granted a certificate under Art. 132 1  of the Constitution of India as in his opinion the case involved a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellant urged before Judicial Commissioner that s.421 CrPC offends Art.14 as it discriminates between convicted persons in jail and others.

anchor.surface_text: It had been urged before the Judicial Commissioner that s. 421 of the Code of Criminal Procedure which enabled a companyrt to dismiss an appeal filed by a companyvicted person, while he was in jail, without hearing him offended against Art. 14 of the Constitution as it discriminated between him and a companyvicted person who presented his appeal either in person or through a pleader.

facts.text: Appeal through pleader on October 31 1955 rejected as not maintainable due to prior dismissal under s.420.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, on October 31, 1955, he filed a Memorandum of Appeal through a pleader which was rejected on November 1, 1955, on the ground that it was number maintainable owing to his appeal from jail under s. 420 of the Code of Criminal Procedure having been dismissed on October 28, 1955.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that s.421 does not offend Art.14.

anchor.surface_text: There is, therefore, a rational basis for making the classification into three categories which has a reasonable companynection with the object of the Code. It companyld number therefore be said that the proviso to s 421 offends against the provisions of Art. 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Order dismissing appeal on October 28 1955 was lawful and final under s.430 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: If that order was lawfully made the decision of the Appellate Court was final under s. 430 of the Code. Consequently, the appeal presented by the appellant through his pleader on October 31, 1955, was patently number maintainable.

facts.text: Second appeal through pleader not maintainable after dismissal of jail appeal.

anchor.surface_text: It is sufficient to say that if the order dated October 28, 1955, dismissing the appellants appeal under s. 420 was lawful, a second appeal from the same judgment of companyviction presented through a pleader was number maintainable because the previous order of the High Court dismissing the appeal was final under s. 430 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

Section 419 enjoins that every appeal shall be made in the form of a petition in writing presented by the appellant or his pleader and every such petition shall, unless the court to which it is presented otherwise directs, be accompanied by a copy of the judgment or order appealed against and in cases tried by jury a copy of the heads of the charge recorded under S. 367.

anchor.surface_text: Section 410 enables any person convicted at a trial held by a Sessions Judge or an Additional Sessions Judge to appeal to the High Court. The Court of Judicial Commissioner, Vindhya Pradesh, was a High Court for the purposes of the Code. The appeal of the appellant from jail against his conviction and sentence by the Sessions Judge therefore lay to the Court of the Judicial Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: Section 404 expressly states that no appeal shall lie from any judgment or order of a criminal court except as provided for by the Code or by any other law for the time being in force. This provision is in accordance with the general principle that no appeal lies as a matter of right unless the right of appeal is conferred by law.

concepts.interpretation: No appeal except as provided by Code or other law.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has decided in many cases what are the matters to be considered in order to determine whether a particular piece of legislation is discriminatory and consequently in contravention of the provisions of Art. 14. It is unnecessary to refer to them. The object of Chapter XXXI of the Code of Criminal Procedure was to make provisions for appeals against conviction in certain cases.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the appellant was in jail and he presented his petition of appeal to the Court of the Judicial Commissioner under s. 420 through the jail authorities. It was summarily dismissed on merits on October 28, 1955. If that order was lawfully made the decision of the Appellate Court was final under s. 430 of the Code.

arguments.claim: Certain cases relied upon by appellant distinguished as none held that lawful dismissal of appeal permits subsequent appeal through pleader

anchor.surface_text: Certain cases were relied upon to which reference has been made by the Judicial Commissioner. Those cases can be distinguished from the present case. holdings.text: It could not therefore be said that the proviso to s 421 offends against the provisions of Art. 14 of the Constitution.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Classification of convicted persons presenting appeals in person, through pleader, or from jail satisfies reasonable classification test under Art. 14 with rational nexus to object of Chapter XXXI CrPC providing for appeals.

holdings.text: If that order was lawfully made the decision of the Appellate Court was final under s. 430 of the Code. Consequently, the appeal presented by the appellant through his pleader on October 31, 1955, was patently not maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the appellant was in jail and he presented his petition of appeal to the Court of the Judicial Commissioner under s. 420 through the jail authorities. It was summarily dismissed on merits on October 28, 1955. If that order was lawfully made the decision of the Appellate Court was final under s. 430 of the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Summary dismissal of jail appeal under s. 421 after perusal is lawful and attains finality under s. 430, barring subsequent appeal from same conviction through pleader.

holdings.text: the order dated October 28, 1955, dismissing the appellants appeal under s. 420 was lawful, a second appeal from the same judgment of conviction presented through a pleader was not maintainable because the previous order of the High Court dismissing the appeal was final under s. 430 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Lawful summary dismissal under s. 420/421 renders appellate order final per s. 430, precluding second appeal on same judgment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Resolution of constitutional challenge to s. 421 confirms substantial question of law regarding constitutional interpretation, but rejects challenge on merits.

holdings.text: Those cases can be distinguished from the present case. In none of them was it decided that where an order dismissing the appeal is lawful a subsequent appeal filed through a pleader was maintainable.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents cited by appellant distinguished as not addressing maintainability of second appeal after lawful dismissal.
